Summary

ID: 52567 Status: Submitted
Entered By: David Copperfield Comparison: Above Average
Entered: Event Type: N/A
Observed: City: Paris
Language: English Country: France
Reviewer: David Copperfield Subject: David Copperfield
Reviewer Level: 3 Existing Level: 3
Reviewer Role: Other Subject Role: Other
Type: Evaluation
Strengths: Rules and Policy Knowledge - I'm still the Rules NetRep and have successfully transitioned it to a forum hosted on JudgeApps from the old listserv-based mailing list. Left to be done are:
- scraping together the old archives and making them searchable somehow without listserv software,
- shutting down the old list and possibly create a redirect to the new forums, with instruction on how to subscribe,
- making sure we have better response times on the forum.
Recently, Igor Delic has been introduced as another official voice on Rules Q&A which is immensely helpful at times when I'm not available, but we still have a median answer time of more than 24 hours. The fact that Johann Eliasson (my most frequent assistant in making sure our answers are correct) moved to the East coast and doesn't show up on IRC at times compatible with mine. A good thing though is that my new job doesn't block IRC, so it's possible I can make up for it by staying connected during the day. I should still make sure my succession is assured in case I need to drop the responsibility; if I become sphere leader for L3 testing, I should still have time for rules; but if I'm appointed RC I think I should just drop Rules Q&A.

Penalty and Policy Philosophy - I used to put this as an AFI for many years, mainly since I wasn't all that interested in what's behind policy. But recently, having mentored several L3s, having participated in many panels, and more generally holding policy discussions more frequently, I've come to realize that policy is not so arcane. Most of it has logical grounds and it's not simply a system that happens to work in most cases, but by comparing with other possibilities it's pretty close to a local energy minimum (sorry, physicist jargon here but at least I understand myself). As such I'm now able to discuss in-depth many convoluted scenarios and place them correctly within our policy. Creating role plays on the spot has been quite a fun exercise during panels when we discover that the usual scenarios would not show what we want of candidates. In addition, I've become more recently involved in a policy group (bluffing). While I'm not super involved right now due to time constraints, I'm not shying away anymore as I would have a year or two ago.

Self-Evaluation - while I don't sopntaneously self-review that often anymore, it's not for lack of self-reflection. It's still an exercise I'm comfortable doing, since I know I don't have to prove anything to anyone, I'm fit as I am and have no problems being honest about myself. One thing that has been a bit less good recently is the lack of cohesive plan for my judging, but I think it's more a lack of focus or self-motivation than a lack of ability at creating and following one. This year has been a transition year for me, changing jobs and all, but now that that part of my life has settled, I'll have more time to devote to other areas.

Attitude and Maturity - This is probably an area I would have never thought myself putting in AFI (and still aren't today), but it's always something to keep in mind. Ever since early early years when I was bragging left and right (the issues that come with being gifted at something) and then put back into my place and rightly so by a few senior judges, I've been very careful (and sometimes even a bit too thoughtful) about my behavior and appearance. Over the years I've become more confident and more comfortable with my persona and that has contributed to transforming me from a lackadaisycal to a jovial guy and someone fun to judge with. I still have limits to sociability (for example, I hate social activities such as karaoke or night clubs; and won't usually be staying too late at judge dinners), but I know them well and know how to get around them gracefully and above all not to annoy other people with them. One thing I've improved especially this year is my ability to notice when I'm in a bad mood and adjusting my tasks accordingly so that I don't bother other people (for example I'll stay behind a laptop and do some admin stuff). This leads to increasing other judges confidence in me since they'll see me under the best conditions only.

Program Construction and Philosophy - Not much to say here, other than I thought I understood much better how L4+ worked and what promotion to L4 worked, until Jean-Maurice was promoted and I still don't understand why. Don't get me wrong, I totally do not think he didn't deserve it, it's just that there's yet another aspect ot L4 promotion which I didn't know about. I don't necessarily pursue L4 myself (as in, would be nice being one and especially get to HJ GPs, but I'm also ok with continuing and my current level), but I sometimes fail to see the logic of promotions. For example, I would have seen Yamamoto and Bob promoted before Jeam-Maurice. But that's just me. We concluded after debating that Jean-Maurice must have been promoted for dealing with lots of behind-the-scenes issues; and because it was behind-the-scenes no one knew about it outside of privileged spheres.

Investigations - Exposure to a wide variety of situations has helped me gain experience in this area where I am already feeling quite at ease. Having DQed close to 20 players over the years, it probably means I've done anywhere between 50 and 100 investigations. Mind-boggling just to think of it! One specific area I haven't yet fully mastered is handling of violent players. One case this year at GP Ibiza left me a bit shaken, with a player who was on the verge of exploding. Maybe the appropriate response is better physical fitness... Or just accept that occasionally things can go bad. But in this case we handled the situation in a satisfactory manner and the player even greeted me with a smile on the next event.

Stress and Conflict Management - Aside from the violent player situation just above, I seem to be able to handle most 1-on-1 situations rather well. I'm still a bit uneasy when it comes to handling a large amount of things with little preparation (I typically hate being public events manager, as it's close to impossible to have decent planning that one can stick to). If I can prepare accordingly, such as HJ of SCG opens, I have absolutely no problem performing well under pressure.

Teamwork and Diplomacy - I've learned to better adapt to various roles in judging. I tended to be rather obnoxious when I wasn't satisfied of how someone was leading - insubordination, public questioning of decisions, and other behavioral mistakes - you name it, I've done it. But no more. I know well how to fit in most teams now, helped in this by experiences at numerous GPs abroad, including South America and Asia. I now tend to err on the other side, questioning people too little (more on this below), but all-in-all I'm rather easy to work with.

Communication - Me forget how to talk English since I date Chloe. Joke aside, writing regularly for the rules Q&A, reviews, and various reports/articles force me to stay sharp whenever I write. Every single area of my life now involves speaking English, so even though my vocabulary and especially grammar might not be perfect, I have ample practice in being understood and feel I'm not doing too bad.
Areas for Improvement: Judge Assessment - while I have consistently been an excellent and prolific reviewer, I have reviewed much less this year than previous ones. This is partly due to me devoting more efforts to other parts of the program (I spent the first months this year trying to improve deck-checking at Grand Prix), but also to laziness. Even though I've never liked sitting down with someone just to review them (as opposed to having a general chat which I quite enjoy), I did force myself to do so in previous years. This year I've been avoiding it, which probably led ot at least 30% less reviews. I did make the effort to make reviews at important times (481047 on Fritz, 520318 on Jose, 498819 on Udobata), but for others haven't made the effort unless explicitly asked to (for example I didn't review Chialuka despite abundant material, based on the excuse that I offered twice to recommend him but he didn't say yes. Dedication should mandate me to do so anyway). One possible explanation (although it's by no means an excuse) is that I've been less encouraged to sit down with judges. Larry used to check that I was doing it, especially in my late years as L2 and first couple as L3. I also had the motivation around 2010-11 to do lots of follow-ups due to responsibilities in the French federation (which has since almost disappeared from the scene). Nowadays, I'm supposed to be more self-motivated and am less so. The change of French RC should solve part of the problem, as I would certainly feel that reviews go towards a more general goal instead of being lost in a limbo.

Leadership, Presence and Charisma - this is also an area where I've become weaker over the years, especially at the national level. One very good reason for this is that an excellent generation of L3s has emerged since 2010 and I've been quite keen on leaving more space to the newcomers, whereas I used to have to do almost everything myself for lack of other leadership. One pretty bad reason is the lack of faith I had in Zacharie as an RC, so had little morivation to fo an help him and as an extension to help the French community. I've been gaining some ground internationally, but mostly to the level of just a good L3 and not as ambitiously as I could have been in younger years. As thus I've focused mostly on own interests, that is the L3 testing process in which I've been very involved, doing perharps more panels that anyone else in the past 3-4 years, as well as participating in various connected activities such as PEIs. I've recently applied to lead that sphere. But on a national level my leadership is far from being what it used to be. That's not helped by the fact that we have no more Nationals, that due to various circumstances I'm not judging often at Bazaar of Moxen, and that I have very little motivation to participate in Judge Conferences. TL;DR: my plan of action is to assist the new RC more.

Mentorship - that's also linked to the above lack of interest in national judging. I've been participating in lots of teamwork at Grand Prix, helping make sure that work is done in a fun and efficient manner, but I think overall that my contribution to teaching others isn't that great. I prefer leading in a task-oriented, fun-having approach than spending countless hours in deep policy discussions and other personal feedback. It's not that I'm unable to do it, but generally I don't enjoy it that much. One workaround I've developed is answering questions with questions, hopefully giving food for though for other judges that will lead them to the right answer (and teach them how to get there) rather than just giving the answer straight away. This is teaching on the cheap but it works rather well in practice. One thing I don't have is metric for this. On the other hand, I recall Larry having a profound impact on me and something that struck me was his ability to come up with elaborate exercices that would teach one some concept in a very organic and very effective way.
Comments: This is a 2013 self-review.

Transition year with more focus on non-judge stuff this year, which might continue next year since Chloe and I are going to live in different cities and seeing each other will likely eat up some free time. On the other hand, more travel means more opportunity to write, so it might balance out in the end and I might stay as active as now if not more. Much of that will also depend on the outcome of RC selection and L3 testing sphere leader selection (I hope to get the second one but not the first one!).

See myself in a year.
